title: Macro Live, Fed rate-rise special edition

teaser.title: Macro Live, Fed rate-rise special edition

bodyHTML:
6:22 pm
CG

Sit tight everyone, we'll be getting started at 1:30pm EST (6:30pm in London)

CG

Greetings one and all

CG

Matt will be joining shortly. Rabble, make yourselves known as you enter the fray

6:33 pm
MK

Howdy

CG

With apologies for retweeting myself on a non-Twitter platform:

CG

https://twitter.com/CardiffGarcia/status/677193969768521728

6:34 pm
CG

Hinkly, Gross, paver, outlaw, thanks for joining us

CG

Okay, so what can we expect today?

CG

25bps rise is the expectation, but lots of open-ended questions about:

6:34 pm
CG

1) change in the economic outlook

CG

2) Guidance for how furture rate rises will proceed

CG

3) Mechanics, and specifically how big will the allotment be for the RRP facility?

6:36 pm
MK

The interesting question, which we'll have to wait a bit for, is how much of this was priced in

CG

4) Obviously, will markets react at all given guidance to this point?

CG

Simon, it would prove to have been impressively misleading

6:37 pm
MK

We've seen big moves in short-term rates (repo, libor, bills, OIS, 2yr note etc) and in credit, commods, fx, all presumably in anticipation of what will happen

MK

assuming the Fed follows through with what they've communicated, should we expect any additional price action? or, like ECB, will it turn out to be disappointing in some way?

CG

John Authers in the house, ladies and gents!

6:38 pm
MK

Simon, that's a reasonable assumption, guess we'll have to find out!

CG

Yes, the key reason to believe they have to go through with a hike today is to ask the question: What would she say in the press conference if they don't go through with a hike? That would be one of the most difficult press conferences of all time.

CG

Indeed

6:39 pm
MK

Speaking of what Icarus said, anyone care to guess on the size of the RRP allotment?

CG

800bn?

CG

Has the Fed given any guidance on this at all other than "bigger but not full"?

6:41 pm
MK

CG, not that I'm aware of. Personally don't understand why it wouldn't be full allotment

CG

Interesting point by our very own Joe Rennison on the right, passing along Skyrm comment: ""I think the climb in repo rates this past week is 75% banks rebalancing cash/securities for year-end and a 25% expectation of the tightening."

MK

I admit it's been a while since I took econ 101 but I thought you could control either price or quantity but not both

6:41 pm
MK

Thanks Joe!

CG

MCK, I'm totally pro full allotment. Might be restraining it a bit because of optics, but it's silly

MK

(in case you missed the link, here's the latest dealer survey from October https://www.newyor...-results.pdf?la=en via Joe Rennison)

6:42 pm
PM

(Just dropping by to say hello)

CG

Gonna re-up an old link that I like, from our frequent source Zoltan Pozsar: https://doc.resear...hzlqIWMsoyTFCE4%3d

CG

Specifically, a few predictions:

6:43 pm
CG

1. The Fed will opt for a full allotment o/n RRP facility on the day of liftoff.

CG

2. Fed funds effective will print around 35 bps with risks to the upside.

CG

3. 3-mo Libor will print around 55 bps with risks strongly to the upside.

6:44 pm
CG

4. Liftoff will benefit some banks but hurt others. A rising tide – rising interest
rates – will not lift all boats as is typical during hiking cycles.

CG

5. Volatility may spike in the 3-5 year segment of the U.S. Treasury curve as
deposit flows force banks to calibrate their HQLA portfolios.

CG

6. A full allotment RRP facility could accelerate FX reserve managers’ shift
out of euros for U.S. dollars.

6:45 pm
CG

teepee, seems a safe assumption

CG

hello, Drago, Ranko, Icarus, doresetcontrarian, thanks for joining

CG

We're now 15 minutes away from the new statement, economic projections, and implementation guidance

6:45 pm
CG

Let's do a markets check

CG

Robin, Joe, rabble, help us out!

MK

Drago that's a great question

6:48 pm
MK

I think the short version is that the Fed doesn't want to get into the business of competing with banks for retail and corp deposits

MK

tying its deposit system to the size of the balance sheet, which it hopes to eventually shrink, could reduce the likelihood of MMMFs holding big deposits at the Fed on a permanent basis

CG

But it's also because the Fed wants to make sure that collateralized rates are in line with unsecured

6:50 pm
CG

That's the very point -- converging secured and unsecured rates, maintaining control over both

MK

Sure although it's not clear why an unsecured deposit at the Fed would be meaningfully different from a repo secured by a UST. Backed by American govt either way.

CG

This, on rate rises and emerging markets, is both amusing and clever:

6:51 pm
CG

https://twitter.com/_sidverma/status/677117614808764417

CG

Hello CanadaW and the indifferent zoomy boy

MK

Teepee that's a reasonable question

6:52 pm
MK

There have been times in the past when bills and Fed funds moved in different directions, often during crises

MK

In normal times I would suspect they move together because the Fed is trading bills to adjust size of bank reserves and hit Fed funds target

CG

RobinWigglesworth: The 10-year Treasury has nudged slightly below 2.3% again, S&P still merrily higher on the day.

6:53 pm
CG

Thanks Robin

CG

S&P up almost half a percentage point today, to 2053

CG

Nabil Ez-zaoui, possibility for another Greenspan-esque "condundrum" is of course one of the big unknowns

6:55 pm
MK

Hinkley that would be consistent with a 25 bps increase from 5 bps, no idea whether it will do that or opt for more straightforward 25 bps floor

MK

This comes from Joe Rennison:

MK

Jerome Schneider, head of short-term and funding desk at Pimco: “We'll be watching the reaction of the 2-year Treasury compared to the "blue dots" in the Fed's Summary of Economic Projections (SEP). We expect the Fed to signal a gradual rate hike cycle, while reaffirming that policy remains data dependent.

“We're also looking at whether the Fed will increase the size of its repo facility beyond the current $300billion which would demonstrate the Fed's commitment to drain excess reserves by using this new monetary tool, while simultaneously providing market participants with another avenue to Invest excess cash.”

6:59 pm
CG

Here it comes!

CG

Will show up here: http://www.federal.../fomccalendars.htm

MK

(hyperventilating)

7:00 pm
MK

they did it

MK

Someone on a terminal want to check Dec 2018 eurodollars?

CG

http://www.federal...tary/20151216a.htm

7:01 pm
MK

http://www.federal...ary/20151216a1.htm

CG

no dissents

CG

Kept "gradual" in there

7:02 pm
CG

a mild surprise

CG

In light of the current shortfall of inflation from 2 percent, the Committee will carefully monitor actual and expected progress toward its inflation goal. The Committee expects that economic conditions will evolve in a manner that will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate; the federal funds rate is likely to remain, for some time, below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run.

MK

Here's the SEP http://www.federal...ojtabl20151216.pdf

7:03 pm
MK

Simon what was it before?

CG

Only mild changes in the SEP from what I can see -- unemployment rate and inflation projections for next year slightly lower, growth mostly the same too

PM

This was 100% priced in

7:04 pm
PM

There's little no reaction to speak of

CG

Another decline in the central tendency for the long-run unemployment rate (Nairu proxy)

CG

From [4.9 – 5.2] to [4.8 – 5.0]

7:06 pm
MK

Looks like eurodollars expecting lower rate by end of 2015 than almost all the dots, per SimonH

PM

(30yr yields are falling -- but will get a pick of the wobble)

PM

7:09 pm
CG

Trajectory for the path of rates has flattened somewhat in the SEPs as well

CG

S&P now climbing again

MK

https://twitter.com/ylanmui/status/677203585764036608

7:09 pm
PM

Yes, and the Dow's up over a ton

PM

Wrap from Sam Fleming here: http://www.ft.com/...html#axzz3uVqOrogv

MK

To be more precise, full allotment: "in amounts limited only by the value of Treasury securities held outright in the System Open Market Account" https://www.newyor...ting_policy_151216

7:14 pm
CG

full-ish allotment, then

CG

Moving this over from the right, via Robin W, from Aberdeen:

CG

“The Fed has finally started to raise interest rates. It would have been catastrophic communication muck up if they hadn’t raised rates today. Having resolved one uncertainty, the question will now turn to the pace of hikes next year. The Fed is signalling four hikes next year, which is significantly more than is expected by the market. In the last few years, it is the Fed forecasts that have been wrong and the market right. We may finally be at the tipping point, where the market starts to take the Fed’s own forecasts more seriously.”

7:15 pm
MK

Press conference will be streamed here

PM

Here's some Simon Derrick, BNY Mellon

MK

http://www.ustream.tv/federalreserve

7:16 pm
CG

Shallower path than before, still steeper than market expects

PM

Given that former Fed Chair Ben Bernanke first began talking about about investors reaching for yield back in May of 2013, today's move by the FOMC might count as the most pre signalled policy shift in modern history. It is therefore a measure of how monetary policy (and its corollary, currency policy) is drowning out almost all other signals that today's meeting has dominated market thinking in recent weeks. This is not to downplay the importance of the first US rate hike in close to a decade (an eternity for financial markets) but, nevertheless, it rings alarm bells for those (like us) that worry about the underlying instability of the current market environment (see our 2016 preview https://www.bnymel.../2016-preview.jsp). So what do we make of today's decision to hike policy by 25 bp and the subsequent price action?

The first thing that strike us is that, as we have been arguing, the Fed has proved slightly more dovish than expected (emphasising in particular the word "gradual"). Given the forces in play (most notably the disinflationary forces in play - from lower oil prices to a stronger USD) this was to be expected. This, then, is starting to look like the environment we thought would emerge with a Fed that, while hawkish, is careful not to disturb the markets equanimity. Looking ahead to 2016 this therefore looks like the USD bullish and equity market bullish environment we thought would emerge.

PM

(outlaw -- yes, definite flattening of the curve, but not dramatic)

7:17 pm
MK

As is often the case, the hold music for the press conference stream is really mellow

MK

This would have been more appropriate as music, imho https://www.youtub...atch?v=up0t2ZDfX7E

MK

unless of course they're trying to signal mellowness

7:19 pm
CG

zoomy boy, best to think of it as a corridor

CG

of multiple policy rates rather than one

CG

zoomy, there isn't just one -- IOER the upper bound, RRPs the lower bound, fed effective to fluctuate within

7:21 pm
MK

@outlaw, lol

CG

did @outlaw just rickroll you?

CG

9 minutes until the presser

7:21 pm
CG

Sam "green eggs and ham" Fleming repping the FT

MK

Of course Wigglesworth is going to cite a Norwegian asset manager

MK

Here's the quote:

7:22 pm
MK

"The Fed is not in a serious tightening mood. As I see it we should not expect a series of rate hikes after today's lift-off.

The Fed might wait for a long time before they hike again, and Ms. Yellen could possibly reverse course and decrease the target for the federal funds rate again.

As I read the press release, the Fed's reaction function, i.e. how the fed respond to new macroeconomic data, is dovish, and probably more so than the market expected. Should GDP growth and/or the employment advance taper off a bit, or should core inflation, which on the Fed's preferred gauge currently is 1.3%, not increase toward the Fed's 2% target during Q1, the tightening mission will be put on hold or aborted."

CG

who's got a 2- and 10-year update handy?

CG

"SimonH: 2-year: 0.984, 10-year: 2.275"

7:24 pm
CG

Ta

These have barely moved, to be clear

MK

https://twitter.com/EricGPlatt/status/677207726783643648/photo/1

7:25 pm

OUtlaw -- http://www.ustream...aign=notifications

MK

Assuming, rather generously, these forecasts of rate are correct, what do you all think the FF rate will peak at this tightening cycle?

And when?

https://twitter.com/tomgara/status/677207894295715845

CG

Accurate

WYSIWYG, damn! That's quite pessimistic

BTW, Wells Fargo has already said they're raising rates on credit cards and home equity loans but not deposits

Here we go!

Presser time

7:31 pm

"recognizes the considerable progress that has been made"

"confidence the economy will continue to strengthen"

MK

"recovery not yet complete"

Inflation still below longer run objective

"economy performing well" "even after this increase, monetary policy remains accommodative"

modest increase now appropriate, "remains accommodative"

expect we'll be hearing that phrase a lot in this presser

2.3 million jobs created this year

"2.3 million jobs have been added" -- context would be helpful by comparing to what is needed to close employment gap

"some cyclical weakness likely remains"

"solid improvement" in some indicators of remaining labor market slack, including part-time-looking-for-full-time

Yellen thinks some of the decline in labor participation will reverse as economy continues to improve

"purchases of motor vehicles have been particularly strong" -- subprime auto FTW

MK

"developments abroad still pose risks to US economic growth"

expect 2% inflation within medium term -- remember Yellen has previously defined medium term as 2-6 years forward

7:36 pm

much of the inflation shortfall down to energy, expecting this influence to decline

MK

@EAO not sure about hike per se, but credit in auto has been abundant, will be interesting to see how sales hold up if credit terms tighten at all. longer-lived cars have supported resale values

MK

"Our statement emphasizes...we will carefully monitor actual and expected progress to our inflation goal"

7:37 pm

It's a goal not a target!

EAO, keep in mind impact of lower gas prices too

MK

If you want a little more insight into Yellen's own thinking about the inflation goal, may I humbly direct you to this old post: http://ftalphavill...ou-think-it-means/

7:39 pm

"as transitory factors holding down inflation abate...median inflation projections rises to 1.6% next year"

those transitory factors being oil and the dollar

"the stance of monetary policy remains accommodative"

"tighter underwriting standards" held back the economy, allegedly

"We anticipate continuing [principal reinvestments] until normalization is well underway"

IOER to 0.5%, RRP at 0.25% -- to ensure control, suspended the aggregate cap

Q&A starting now

First one from AP:

Hello!

(that's my question)

Yellen's fear of abrupt tightening is what motivated Fed to do what it did in 2004-6 following experience in 1994-5

By the way this paper http://econweb.ucs...lto/USMPF_2015.pdf makes a good case for delaying tightening as long as possible because tightening rapidly later would be better than gradual with early start

"I think it's a myth expansions die of old age"

I would have been impressed if Yellen had answered "we don't want people to get pay rises that are too big so we're trying to restrain economic growth to keep unemployment sufficiently elevated?"

Next question from American Banker on interest rate risk for banks

8:23 pm

From Dan McCrum:

MK

Rick Rieder, CIO fixed income at BlackRock:From a cyclical peak of 10% in October 2009, the unemployment rate stands today at 5%. Three very solid years of 225,000 jobs/month gained has taken a massive number of qualified applicants out of the unemployment pool and created more than 8 million jobs over this period. Thus, we would suggest that the rate of payrolls growth may well slow in the year ahead, which could complicate the FOMC’s task. It also suggests that more weight may be placed on building wage pressures and broader inflation when considering future rate increases.

MK

The problem with this idea of "expected progress" on inflation is that their models are designed so that inflation always gets back to 2% in a few years because of anchored expectations

MK

and the idea of "anchored expectations" is based mostly on faith rather than real data

"There can be negative spillovers through capital flows, but there are also positive spillovers from strong US economy"

Next question is about wage growth

right, that's what I meant

those either

8:38 pm

MK

I'll be honest I'm confused by the narrative about importance of gradual hikes as a way to prevent a downturn caused by rapid hikes

MK

What does she think caused the 2007-9 recession? or the 2000-2002 recession? or the 1989-1991 recession? Fed tightened in each one, sure, but it wasn't Volcker-style

8:41 pm
CG

I don't know how convincing I find her point about avoiding a later steep rise to ward off an inflationary spike, but that's the narrative she has settled on. And it's consistent with her very first innovation, which is that the path of rate hikes would be shallower than what historically would be expected given wider econ indicators. That said

CG

the predicted path remains steeper than the market anticipates, and so there will be either a gradual (hopefully) or perhaps not-so-gradual reckoning in the next couple of years

MK

@Londo entirely possible there will be no impact even if short rates go past 100 bps, the yield curve is steep enough to include a lot of tightening, remember the conundrum?

8:43 pm
CG

But I didn't leave today thinking "Ooh that's more hawkish/dovish than expected". And frankly the full-ish allotment of the RRP seems a step in the right direction from a purely mechanical perspective

CG

And I still say a permanently bigger balance sheet is just fine, no need to run from it

CG

That's it from me

8:43 pm
CG

MK, your takeaways?

MK

@Londo I would say if they didn't hike at this point longer rates would fall

MK

My main takeaway, aside from agreeing with you 100% about their success in telegraphing what would happen, is this focus on gradual vs rapid tightening

8:45 pm
MK

It's something the Fed used to say under Greenspan when talking about the importance of soft landings and avoiding inflation overshoots

MK

But it's not something we've heard for a long time in the context of this recession and recovery

MK

It also seems outdated

8:46 pm
MK

In the 1970s and early 1980s, inflation did overshoot and Fed did have to raise rates by massive amounts over short periods, and the result was big swings in output

MK

Hasn't been true in past 30 years though

CG

Yeah I still find it confusing too, seems like one of those reasons you arrive at after the decision has been made, because "We're worried about financial stability" is still too controversial a reason to use explicitly for overriding current inflationary trends. That's my best guess.

8:47 pm
CG

(A guess at an explanation, mind you, not saying I agree or disagree with that actual logic.)

so I guess they haven't tightened that much!
